body:
How about using `containsOnly` ?

The following assertions succeed:

``` java
assertThat(objects).containsOnly(first, second, third, first).
assertThat(objects).containsOnly(first, second, third).
```

but maybe you don't the second one to pass ?

Yes, I don't want the second one to pass.
I need to assert over all the elements, including duplicates, but without order.
ok, I like the name, it's consistent with the other assertions.

issue.title: Add containsExactlyInAnyOrder Assertion for primitive arrays

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body: `containsExactlyInAnyOrder` was added with https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/issues/572 but is missing for primitive arrays.

body: It would be nicer to overload this method taking iterable as parameter.

@Sean-PAN2014 No sure I understand you correctly, but you can use `containsExactlyInAnyOrder` with  iterables: http://joel-costigliola.github.io/assertj/core/api/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractIterableAssert.html#containsExactlyInAnyOrder(ELEMENT...)
@filiphr yeah, that's exactly what I mean.
